The number of Covid-19 deaths rose slightly to 2.11 percent due to the continuing harmonization of data together with the Philippine Statistics Authority, de Guzman said. Meanwhile, Dr. Guido David of the Octa Research Group has warned that if the uptrend in Cebu City continues, the city’s hospital bed capacity will exceed the current 850 beds, with occupancy reaching up to 1,200 by March 1. The country logged 1,734 Covid cases on Thursday, for a total of 543,282 cases. The DoH also said it has traced the lone case of the new Covid-19 variant who listed Liloan, Cebu, as his hometown, in Quezon City, where he is now isolated. The Quezon City government said the 35-year-old male moved to Sucat, Parañaque City and made frequent visits to his manning agency in Malate, Manila. His last visit was on
January 14 after he secured another overseas placement. While waiting for deployment, the man rode a cab and stayed in a hotel in Manila on January 17, where he took a swab test. His results returned positive the same day and his sample was sent to the Philippine Genome Center until January 21, when his agency booked a ride-hailing cab and transferred him to an apartment in Riverside in Commonwealth, Quezon City. The genome sequencing results released on February 5 showed that he was positive for the B117 variant. Three days later, he developed a mild cough. De Guzman said the patient, a former overseas Filipino worker, traveled from Cebu to Manila to process his papers. He added that because of the patient’s mobility, the case investigation now involves several cities where he made his contacts.

headlines: PH records 1,734 new Covid cases
contents: THE Philippines has logged 1,734 new cases of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19), raising the count to 543,282, the Department of Health (DoH) said on Thursday. More than 95 percent of the 31,478 active cases were either mild, moderate or asymptomatic while the rest, or almost 5 percent, were critical or severe. At least 500,335 have recovered from the virus while 11,469 have died. The DoH-accredited Covid laboratories have conducted 26,910 tests, 1,396 of which returned positive for a positivity rate of 5.2 percent.

headlines: House on ABS-CBN franchise: ‘Wait until next Congress’
contents: CALLS to revive the franchise of media network ABS-CBN will have to wait “until the next Congress” or in 2022, when the current administration ends, Speaker Lord Allan Velasco said on Thursday. Velasco issued the statement three days after President Rodrigo Duterte said he would not allow the continued operations of the network even if Congress granted a new franchise, claiming that ABS-CBN had unpaid taxes. Velasco said the House of Representatives will focus on priority legislation of the Duterte administration and measures against the coronavirus disease (Covid-19) pandemic. “With a little over a year until the 2022 elections, the House of Representatives is bent on finishing the remaining priority measures of this Administration to ensure that President Rodrigo Roa Duterte fulfills his campaign promise to the Filipino people,” he said. “On top of these priority legislation, we would like to see the passage of Bayanihan 3, as well as other economic bills geared toward rebuilding the Philippine economy shattered by the devastating impact of the global pandemic and rebuilding the lives of every Filipino disrupted by the health crisis,” he added.

headlines: Duterte: PH ‘ready to work constructively’ with EU despite vaccine hostage claim
contents: THE Philippines is ready to work with the European Union (EU)  for the “greater good” of the people, President Rodrigo Duterte said, despite recently accusing the bloc of holding coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccines “hostage.” In his speech in Malacañang on Wednesday, Duterte stressed the need to “redefine, refine, and reinforce” the ties between the Philippines and the EU in the face of new challenges and opportunities. “The Philippines and the EU share a deep respect for democracy and the rule of law. This will serve as a solid foundation for robust cooperation on the basis of mutual trust, respect, and benefit. Ours is a long-standing relationship dating back to 1964,” Duterte  told EU Ambassador to the Philippines Luc Véron who presented his credentials in a ceremony Wednesday. The President said he was encouraged by the launch of the sub-committee on good governance, rule of law and human rights under Manila and EU’s Partnership and Cooperation Agreement on February 5, which serve as a formal platform where views and concerns on issues related to human rights would be raised and discussed. The next Philippines-EU Sub-Committee meeting is expected to be held in the country in 2022. “This signifies our shared resolve to implement this landmark agreement notwithstanding the pandemic,” he said. During the Wednesday’s ceremony, Duterte also accepted the credentials of four other envoys—Brazilian Ambassador to the Philippines Antonio Jose Maria De Souza E Silva, South Korean Ambassador to the Philippines Kim In-Chul, French Ambassador to the Philippines Michéle Boccoz, and Colombian Ambassador to the Philippines Marcela Ordoñez.

headlines: Covid-19 drags CIC sales by double digits
contents: Listed Concepcion Industrial Corp. (CIC) reported on Wednesday that its profit after tax and minority interests sank by 50 percent to P471 million in 2020. In a filing, the refrigerator and air-conditioner maker said its unaudited net sales for the year dived by 29 percent to P10.8 billion while overall sales, including those of its Midea air conditioner, fell by 24 percent year-on-year. CIC said the Covid-19 pandemic affected its 2020 results, especially during the height of the community quarantine in the first half. “Our focus throughout 2020 was to ensure our readiness as an organization, even as we put temporary measures to temper the impact of very weak demand,” CIC Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Raul Joseph Concepcion said in the filing. “We continue to make investments in reenergizing our brands, the right technology platforms and innovation as we open the doors to better days ahead in 2021,” he added. According to the company, its second-half results were more encouraging as consumer segment recovery started in the third quarter. Net sales during the period was only down 13 percent, while profit after tax grew by 5 percent to P682 million from breakeven in the first half. CIC shares rose by P1.05 or 5.12 percent to finish at P21.55 each on Wednesday.

headlines: Cebu on the brink
contents: Cebu City’s hospital capacity could reach critical levels if coronavirus cases continue to rise, an academic group that tracks the country’s Covid-19 data warned on Wednesday. Octa Research said Covid-19 cases have spiked in Cebu City since February 1, and if the trend would continue, its hospital capacity would reach critical levels in two weeks. From February 1 to 7, the city averaged 123 new cases per day, 30 percent higher than the 94 cases recorded from January 25 to 31. Its positivity rate also increased to 10 percent and its attack rate to 11.11 per 100,000 population. Neighboring Mandaue and Lapu-Lapu cities also saw spikes, with positivity rates above 10 percent. The group warned that the hospital occupancy in the province might reach 70 percent in two weeks if the current transmission rate of R0 (R-naught) 1.4 and a hospitalization rate of 25 to 35 percent holds. Octa said the increase in the number of cases in the city may be attributed to the presence of the more infectious B117 variant, which was detected in Liloan, Cebu. The Department of Health (DoH) acknowledged that there was an increase in the number of cases in the city but said the spike might not be because of the spread of the new variant that originated in the United Kingdom. “Hindi ho natin masasabi na variant lang ang cause. [Maaring] naka aggravate or makasama sya sa (We can’t say that this variant is the cause. There could be other things that have aggravated it or there were other) factors but it is not the only cause of the numbers increasing in Cebu. Marami pa pong factors ‘yan (There are many factors),” Health Undersecretary Maria Rosario Vergeire said. She said other factors such as gatherings held during the holidays and delays in consultation, wherein some people take three to five days to consult doctors for symptoms after they got exposed to a close Covid-19 contact, could also be behind the spike. Vergeire said the One Hospital Command in Cebu City is managing the situation to prevent a possible surge in hospital care capacity. Octa said the National Capital Region continues to see a flattening trend in the number of Covid-19 cases despite having an R0 of1.02 and an average of 360 new cases per day. Calabarzon (Cavite, Laguna, Batangas, Rizal and Quezon) and Central Luzon had decreased their positivity rate to 5 and 4 percent, respectively, while Davao’s case numbers were also decreasing. Meanwhile, the DoH sought the help of the National Bureau of Investigation to locate a patient with the B117 variant who listed Liloan, Cebu as his hometown to determine his date of exit and see if he had indeed left the country. It is also set to sequence more than 700 samples from the National Capital Region, Calabarzon, Cordillera and Central Visayas to see if there were more cases of the new variant. Vergeire earlier said that the vaccines from the Covax Facility, which consists of the first batch of 117,000 doses of the Pfizer and BioNTech tozinameran vaccine, might arrive on February 13. It will only take two to three days upon arrival for the vaccines to be administered to frontliners in health facilities. The Health Technology Assessment Council gave its approval for the use of tozinameran and AstraZeneca’s AZD1222 vaccines. In its assessment reports released on Feb. 2 and 8, 2021, respectively, the council said both vaccines passed its appraisals. On Wednesday, the DoH logged 1,345 new cases of Covid-19, for a total of 541,560 total cases, of which 30,188 are active. Priority The DoH also said it was open to the proposal of Sen. Christopher Lawrence “Bong” Go to include national athletes in the vaccine priority list. Go urged the government to vaccinate national athletes who would compete in international sporting competitions this year such as the Olympics and the Southeast Asian Games. Vergeire said the DoH was open to the idea, but it has to consult with the interim National Immunization Technical Advisory Group (Nitag) to see if athletes can be prioritized. “Kung hinain natin ito sa Nitag at binigyan natin ng (If we propose this at the Nitag and we would start the) discussions and they would recommend being included, then we will include them,” Vergeire said. She said frontline healthcare workers would be the first to get jabs. “Wala pong ibang sektor ang mawawala sa listahan just because of this request. Ilalagay lang natin sa konteksto, and we will discuss this with experts so we can find the best way possible para maconsider itong mga ganitong (No other sectors will be removed in the list just because of this request. We will just put this into context, and we will discuss with experts so we can find the best way possible to consider this) request,” Vergeire said.

headlines: Covid-19 gets deadlier — and tougher to stop
contents:
IF you think the rapid development and dissemination of vaccines would finally tame the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or SARS-CoV-2, which causes coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19), think again. Besides the unprecedented challenges and risks of developing, testing, procuring, transporting, storing, and administering vaccines within extremely tight time frames to billions of people — everything never been done before — there’s the possibility that SARS-CoV-2 mutations, which have been happening since the virus first spread from Wuhan, Central China, over a year ago, may make it deadlier and harder to stop, even with immunization. Indeed, a new British study now undergoing peer review has calculated a 30-percent greater death risk from the more infectious SARS-CoV-2 variant B117, first detected in the United Kingdom last September and found in at least 70 countries, including the Philippines, as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) in late January. This greater fatality risk could be as high as 35 percent. That means if past coronavirus strains killed 1,000 people a day, the new one could snuff out 1,350 lives, according to the study by the Center for Mathematical Modelling of Infectious Diseases (CMMID) at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine (https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.02.01.21250959v1). The CMMID researchers estimated “that the hazard of death among SGTF [or B117] cases is 30 percent … higher than among non-SGTF cases after adjustment for age, sex, ethnicity, deprivation level, care home residence, local authority of residence and date of test.” And taking account of misclassification of UK-variant patients, the estimated fatality risk would be 35 percent more. What’s worse, there are signs in a small number of UK cases that the British variant may have a mutation first seen in the South African and Brazilian variants, which makes the coronavirus less vulnerable to antibodies produced by people with Covid-19 or vaccination. If confirmed by more data from a wider range of cases, this additional mutation, called E484K, would make B117, which is already more transmissible by as much as 70 percent, also more resistant to immunization. In short, Covid-19 is getting deadlier and harder to stop. Wear masks and find cures
These findings are still being validated by more research. But strategic risk analysis would point to two likely and worrisome trends. First, more infectious variants like B117 will eventually predominate, since it infects more people and spreads faster than the older strains. Moreover, mutations resistant to antibodies would also become prevalent, since more of such strains survive than past ones. Indeed, as immunization spreads, resistant variants would become dominant sooner since the nonresistant ones would die out faster due to vaccinations. These risk factors underscore the imperative that the world continue mask wearing and other prevention protocols and work not only on vaccines but also cures, especially for severe cases that fill hospitals and morgues. The provision of Covid-19 remedies would also consume far less resources than vaccination. For one thing, severe cases requiring medical treatment constitute just a tiny fraction of the population, while vaccination must cover more than half the nation for it to prevent massive deaths. Moreover, a number of remedies have been developed by repurposing existing medications like hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin, which are often cheap compared with newly developed vaccines. And the side effects of these formulations are already well known, so they can be prescribed with proper safeguards. And if the state expands intensive care units and ventilators nationwide, these facilities would be of use for years and for other illnesses besides Covid-19, unlike vaccines. Hence, in its pandemic responses and budgeting, the government must give as much consideration to medical treatment of the thousands of severe Covid-19 cases as rolling out vaccines for tens of millions of Filipinos, purchased with many billions of dollars in loans which would burden the economy for many years. For this reason, we commend the Department of Science and Technology and its Philippine Council for Health Research and Development for their programs and funding to develop local Covid-19 remedies. One that this writer is involved with is the formulation and testing of a drug combining the anti-inflammatory medicine methylprednisolone and the anesthetic procaine, pushed by Covid cure advocate Ruby Ann Kagaoan and undertaken by the De La Salle Medical and Health Sciences Institute in Dasmariñas, Cavite, and the University of the Philippines College of Pharmacy in Manila. Plainly, with vaccines not only hugely expensive and difficult to deploy, but also unsure of success due to coronavirus mutations, the Philippines must make sure to develop and deploy medication and facilities for severely ill Covid-19 patients, who will continue to be among us, vaccines or no vaccines.

headlines: Manila provides monthly food subsidies to 700K families
contents: THE Manila government on Wednesday began the distribution of food packs in line with the city’s Food Security Program (FSP) that aims to subsidize about 700,000 families monthly. Mayor Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso said the program is aimed to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). “Uunahin na muna natin ang tao sa lungsod ng Maynila,” Domagoso said during a meeting with department heads. (We should prioritize the people in the city of Manila first.) The food subsidy includes three kilos of rice, 16 pieces of various canned goods and eight sachets of coffee. The local government allocated P3 billion for the program.

headlines: WHO team: Coronavirus unlikely to have leaked from China lab
contents: WUHAN, China: The coronavirus most likely first appeared in humans after jumping from an animal, a team of international and Chinese scientists looking for the origins of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) said Tuesday, saying an alternate theory that the virus leaked from a Chinese lab was unlikely. A closely watched visit by World Health Organization (WHO) experts to Wuhan — the Chinese city where the first coronavirus cases were discovered — did not dramatically change the current understanding of the early days of the pandemic, said Peter Ben Embarek, the leader of the WHO mission. But it did “add details to that story,” he said at a news conference as the group wrapped up a four-week visit to the city. And it allowed the joint Chinese-WHO team to further explore the lab leak theory — which former US President Donald Trump and officials from his administration had put forward without evidence — and decide it was unlikely. The Wuhan Institute of Virology is home to many different virus samples, leading to allegations that it may have been the source of the original outbreak, whether on purpose or accidentally. Peter Ben Embarek of the World Health Organization team holds up a chart showing pathways of transmission of the virus during a joint press conference held at the end of the WHO mission in Wuhan in central China’s Hubei province on Tuesday, Feb. 9, 2021. (AP Photo/Ng Han Guan) Embarek, a WHO food safety and animal disease expert, said experts now consider the possibility of such a leak so improbable that it will not be suggested as an avenue of future study. But another team member, Danish scientist Thea Koelsen Fischer, told reporters that team members could not rule out the possibility of further investigation and new leads. China had already strongly rejected the possibility of a leak and has promoted other theories. The Chinese and foreign experts considered several ideas for how the disease first ended up in humans, leading to a pandemic that has now killed more than 2.3 million people worldwide. Embarek said the initial findings suggest the most likely pathway the virus followed was from a bat to another animal and then to humans, adding that would require further research. “The findings suggest that the laboratory incidents hypothesis is extremely unlikely to explain the introduction of the virus to the human population,” he said. Liang Wannian, the head of the Chinese side, noted that there was no sample of the virus that causes Covid-19 in the lab — and thus it could not have come from there. The mission was intended to be an initial step in the process of understanding the origins of the virus, which scientists have posited may have passed to humans through a wild animal, such as a pangolin or bamboo rat. Transmission directly from bats to humans or through the trade in frozen food products are also possibilities, Embarek said. The WHO team’s visit is politically sensitive for Beijing, which is concerned about being blamed for alleged missteps in its early response to the outbreak. An AP investigation has found that the Chinese government put limits on research into the outbreak and ordered scientists not to speak to reporters. A WHO-China Joint Study Press Conference is held at the end of a WHO mission to investigate the origins of the coronavirus pandemic in Wuhan in central China’s Hubei province, Tuesday, Feb. 9, 2021. (AP Photo/Ng Han Guan) Still, one member of the WHO team, British-born zoologist Peter Daszak, told The Associated Press last week that they enjoyed a greater level of openness than they had anticipated, and that they were granted full access to all sites and personnel they requested. Koelsen Fischer said she did not get to see the raw data and had to rely on an analysis of the data that was presented to her. But she said that would be true in most countries. The team — which includes experts from 10 countries who arrived on Jan. 14 — visited the Huanan Seafood Market, the site of an early cluster of cases in late 2019. Marion Koopmans, a Dutch virologist on the team, said that some animals at the market were susceptible or suspected to be susceptible to the virus, including rabbits and bamboo rats. And some could be traced to farms or traders in regions that are home to the bats that carry the closest related virus to the one that causes Covid-19. She said the next step would be to look more closely at farms. Liang, the head of the Chinese team, said the virus also appeared to have been spreading in parts of the city other than the market, so it remains possible that the virus originated elsewhere. Marion Koopmans, right, and Peter Ben Embarek, center, of a World Health Organization team look over at their Chinese counterpart Liang Wannian, left, during a WHO-China Joint Study Press Conference held at the end of their mission to investigate the origins of the coronavirus pandemic in Wuhan in central China’s Hubei province, Tuesday, Feb. 9, 2021. (AP Photo/Ng Han Guan) The team found no evidence that the disease was spreading widely any earlier than the initial outbreak in the second half of December 2019. “We haven’t been able to fully do the research, but there is no indication there were clusters before what we saw happen in the later part of December in Wuhan,” Liang said. The visit by the WHO team took months to negotiate. China only agreed to it amid international pressure at the WHO’s World Health Assembly meeting last May, and Beijing has continued to resist calls for a strictly independent investigation. While China has weathered some localized resurgences of infection since getting the outbreak under control last year, life in Wuhan itself has largely returned to normal.

headlines: Pasay City mayor contracts Covid-19
contents: PASAY City Mayor Emi Calixto-Rubiano on Tuesday confirmed that she tested positive for the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). Mayor Emi Calixto-Rubiano. Photo from FB account. She said she started experiencing some Covid-19 symptoms prompting her to immediately get a swab test. “Sa resulta, nakita na ako ay nag-positibo sa nasabing sakit (Results have shown that I tested positive for the said disease),” the mayor said in a Facebook post. She added that the results were released on Monday. The mayor said she and others were exposed to a City Hall employee. They were all required to undergo swab tests. Calixto-Rubiano is now in isolation and ordered her personnel to conduct contact tracing on the employees’ close contacts. “The coronavirus does not choose who to infect. Let us not be complacent, but continue to be careful and cautious,” she said. “This likewise highlights the reality that we really need the vaccination, and our continuous prayers to our Almighty God.” The mayor said she would continue to work via teleconferencing and messaging apps. Pasay has 7,137 cases of the new coronavirus, including 80 active cases, 6,873 recoveries and 184 deaths.

headlines: Time to wear a better mask, experts say
contents: WASHINGTON, D.C.: As new, more transmissible variants of the coronavirus spread, experts say it’s time to consider using a medical-grade respirator, or wearing a surgical and cloth mask together. Scientists have agreed for some time the main way the virus is spread is through the air, rather than surfaces, and there’s growing evidence that small droplets from ordinary breathing and speech that can travel many meters (yards) are a common mode of transmission. Added to this is the greater contagiousness of emerging variants, like B.1.1.7, which takes a smaller viral load to cause symptomatic Covid-19 compared to the more common strain. Back when authorities first recommended people wear face coverings, proper masks were in extremely short supply and the public was encouraged to fashion makeshift solutions out of T-shirts or bandanas. But these are far from ideal. Linsey Marr, a professor of civil and environmental engineering at Virginia Tech, who studies airborne disease transmission, told Agence France-Presse: “How well a mask works depends on two things: filtration and fit. “Good filtration removes as many particles as possible, and a good fit means that there are no leaks around the sides of your mask, where air — and viruses — can leak through,” she said, adding even a small gap could lead to a 50 percent reduction in performance. The best materials for blocking small particles include non-woven polypropylene, which is used to make N95s and many surgical-type masks, and the HEPA filters in planes. Among fabrics, tightly woven cotton works best, she added. This illustration shows a woman wearing two facemasks, a cloth mask over a surgical mask, in Arlington, Virginia, on February 8, 2021. AFP PHOTO “If you wear a cloth mask, choose one that has multiple layers, ideally one with a pocket that you can slip a good filter material into,” said Marr. “Or you can double mask by wearing a surgical-type mask with a tight-fitting cloth mask over it.” Surgical masks are made of material that filters things out well, but they tend to be loose, so adding a cloth mask on top holds down the edges and reduces leaks. Adding an additional layer improves filtration —  if one layer traps 50 percent of all particles, combining two gets to 75 percent. But, she added: “We do not recommend wearing more than two masks. Adding more layers proves diminishing returns and can compromise breathability. It must remain easy to breathe through the layers; otherwise, air is more likely to leak in around the sides of the mask.” Masks that have a metal nose bridge help ensure a snug fit, as do straps that tighten around the head, not just the ears. Braces that improve the fit of surgical masks are now available on the market. “You should feel the mask sucking inward when you breathe in, and if you hold your hands around the sides of the mask, you should not feel any air leaking out when you breathe out,” said Marr. In this file photo taken on January 29, 2021 a woman wearing double protective face masks to prevent the spread of Covid-19 waits at a traffic light in Hanoi, a day after Vietnam recorded its first coronavirus outbreak in almost two months. AFP PHOTO Another option is getting hold of N95s, or their international equivalents such as KN95, FFP2 etc. “They all provide a similar level of filtration, meaning protection of particles going in and out,” Ranu Dhillon, a global health physician at Brigham and Women’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School. Dhillon, who has been advocating in favor of better masks since last spring, is frustrated by the lack of clear messaging to the public on the value of better masks. What’s more, “there’s not been a concerted push to really mass produce and mass distribute these higher caliber masks.” Health care workers have their masks professionally fit-tested every year to ensure they’re making the right seal, but Dhillon doesn’t see this as a major obstacle. “To teach people to fit a mask, even if not 100 percent perfectly, but more effectively, is something that’s very doable.” In this file photo taken on December 10, 2020 a man wears a double mask as he visits Times Square in New York. AFP PHOTO The key to conceptualizing the threat is to think of cigarette smoke, said Donald Milton, a professor of environmental health at the University of Maryland. Ventilation definitely helps, but if you’re between a person who is breathing and an exhaust vent, the virus will still reach you — which makes good masks so crucial, he said. Milton and Dhillon are cautiously optimistic that their pleas could soon become policy under the administration of President Joe Biden, and CNN reported last week the US government was working on the first official mask standards. Prior to the pandemic, Milton and other aerosol scientists studying the flu concluded it too is transmitted from tiny droplets from ordinary speaking and breathing, and that the role of sneezing, coughing and transmission from surfaces was smaller than thought. Their findings stirred controversy at the time, but Covid-19 has renewed interest in the research — meaning masks could be a common sight during tough flu seasons, long after the pandemic has receded.

headlines: Kalinga gov tests positive for Covid
contents: TUGUEGARAO CITY: Kalinga Governor Ferdinand Tubban has announced “with regrets” that he was tested positive for the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). Kalinga Governor Ferdinand Tubban, Photo from Wikipedia In a Facebook post in the provincial government-maintained site, Tubban, who learned of the result on Monday after taking the real time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test, has asked people with whom he had come into contact with in the past week to observe for signs or symptoms of the virus and to consult a health worker. The governor has called on residents to observe minimum health protocols such as washing hands frequently, wearing face mask and face shield and to observe social distancing. It was not immediately known where the governor got the virus. Due to the imposition of the enhanced community quarantine (ECQ) in Tabuk City until February 15, the scholarship renewal of grantees has been postponed indefinitely, according to Mayor Darwin Estranero. The grantees, however, were advised to get their grades and enrollment or assessment form and submit them to the Scholarship Office as soon as schools open after the lockdown. Meanwhile, 116 applications are still pending since May 2020 because the Scholarship Office cannot contact the applicants for an interview due to inactive phone numbers. Uncooperative contacts The municipal health office (MHO) of Lubuagan town in Kalinga is faced with the problem of non-cooperative direct contacts of Covid-19 patients. Mayor Charisma Anne Dickpus urged the public to cooperate in the observance of health protocols and to maintain discipline as a way to combat the spread of Covid-19. Dr. Caroline Agyao, MHO chief, said people who knew they have directly interacted with Covid-19 patients refuse to come forward and cooperate and this has been one of their struggles during contact tracing. “We are begging those that had contact with Covid-19 positive patients to submit themselves. This is also for the protection of the elderly and children who are with them in the same house,” Agyao said. She said some also refuse to reveal their contacts and in one instance resulted in the infection of one of their office staff and that all of them had to be quarantined. “Others even hide and when we conduct random testing in areas identified, we find out that there were those infected with the virus,” Agyao said. Agyao said they welcome the modified enhanced community quarantine (MECQ) status of Lubuagan town because it limits the movement of residents and prohibits them from going in and out of the municipality for non-essential travels. “The extension of the MECQ will also provide them ample time to trace all possible contacts of those who turned positive for Covid-19,” she said. Lubuagan town has recorded a total of 59 cases in the municipality since Nov. 20, 2020 with a total of 36 active cases and 23 recoveries as of February 7.

headlines: Execs: Work-life balance vital amid Covid
contents: Foreign-born corporation chiefs in the Philippines have stressed the importance of maintaining a work-life balance after the coronavirus pandemic disrupted business operations and changed the work arrangements of employers and employees alike. This emerged during a webinar of the French Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday, where these company heads highlighted the vital role of sports and mental health in easing the stress caused by the current working environment, which sees many people still working from home. For Dr. Amal Makhloufi Benchouk, Sanofi Philippines general manager and country chairman, keeping a work-life balance is crucial for a sound body and mind. She said it was important to take care of one’s self, especially since the boundary between the workplace and home had been blurred. According to her, some of the things she does to sustain that balance are setting up specific work times; discouraging meetings during lunch breaks; and dedicating her free time to exercising, learning new skills and her family. She said measures that Sanofi had implemented to ensure the health of its employees included adopting a flexible working scheme, setting a specific time for calls to avoid “Zoom fatigue” and regularly working out to promote physical fitness. The company also launched an employee assistance program that aims to provide workers and their families with services like counselling for both personal and professional situations. “As we go on with our daily lives amid the pandemic and beyond, I would like to prescribe a healthy dose of self-care, which I believe is the best medicine for both our mental and physical health,” Benchouk said. Meanwhile, Decathlon Philippines Chief Executive Officer Hans Iff said sports was important in maintaining a healthy lifestyle. According to him, sports could help release positive hormones that could make one feel happier, relaxed and sensible. Iff also shared a few tips that could help people improve their lifestyle, including creating a routine, keeping some moments to themselves and setting reachable targets. One should learn to listen to one’s body and know one’s limitations, according to him as he emphasized the importance of getting good sleep. For Jones Lang LaSalle Country Head and CCI France Philippines President Cristophe Vicic, the pandemic accelerated his company’s well-being strategy for employees. “The JLL vision is that we want our people to feel supported, engaged and healthy,” Vicic said. According to him, this vision is built on four pillars: mental well-being, physical well-being, financial well-being and inclusion in the workplace. Vicic also attested to his experiences in marathons as having helped him in his career and how he applied the principles of preparing for race in his life and career. For more, watch the edited version of the webinar at The Manila Times YouTube channel: https://youtu.be/PF033nYyid4.

headlines: PH records 1,590 new Covid-19 cases
contents: THE Philippines recorded 1,590 cases of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) on Thursday, according to the Department of Health, increasing the number of infections to 531,699. Of the 32,775 active cases, more than 95 percent are mild, moderate and asymptomatic, while the rest are severe or critical. There are 487,927 recoveries, including 249 new survivors. The death toll is at 10,997 with 55 new fatalities. The country’s positivity rate is at 5.8 percent with 1,428 testing positive for the virus out of the 24,7691 samples sent to laboratories nationwide.

headlines: Study finds Covid-19 vaccine may reduce virus transmission
contents: AstraZeneca’s coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccine shows a hint that it may reduce transmission of the virus and offers strong protection for three months on just a single dose, researchers said on Wednesday in an encouraging turn in the campaign to suppress the outbreak. The preliminary findings from Oxford University, a co-developer of the vaccine, could vindicate the British government’s controversial strategy of delaying the second shot for up to 12 weeks so that more people can be quickly given a first dose. Up to now, the recommended time between doses has been four weeks. The research could also bring scientists closer to an answer to one of the big questions about the vaccination drive: Will the vaccines actually curb the spread of the coronavirus? It’s not clear what implications, if any, the findings might have for the two other major vaccines being used in the West, Pfizer’s and Moderna’s. In the United States, Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, dismissed the idea of deliberately delaying second shots, saying the US will “go by the science” and data from the clinical trials. The two doses of the Pifzer and Moderna vaccines are supposed to be given three and four weeks apart. Still, the research appears to be good news in the desperate effort to arrest the spread of the virus and also suggests a way to ease vaccine shortages and get shots into more arms more quickly. The makers of all three vaccines have said that their shots proved to be anywhere from 70 percent to 95 percent effective in clinical trials in protecting people from illness caused by the virus. But it was unclear whether the vaccines could also suppress transmission of the virus — that is, whether someone inoculated could still acquire the virus without getting sick and spread it to others. As a result, experts have been saying that even people who have been vaccinated should continue to wear masks and keep their distance from others. AstraZeneca vaccine is ready to be used at a homeless shelter in Romford, east London, Wednesday, Feb. 3, 2021. The British health service has started to vaccinate “vulnerable” homeless people. In a study by Oxford University, the AstraZeneca vaccine has been shown to reduce transmission of the virus. AP PHOTO Volunteers in the British study underwent regular nasal swabs to check for the coronavirus, a proxy to try to answer the transmission question. The level of virus-positive swabs — combining volunteers who had asymptomatic infection with those who had symptoms — was 67 percent lower in the vaccinated group, the researchers reported. While not a direct measure, “that’s got to have a really beneficial effect on transmission,” Oxford lead researcher Sarah Gilbert told a meeting of the New York Academy of Sciences Wednesday. The researchers also looked at how likely people who have been vaccinated are to get a symptom-free infection. In one subset of volunteers, there were 16 asymptomatic infections among the vaccinated and 31 in an unvaccinated comparison group. Pfizer and Moderna also are studying the effect of their vaccines on asymptomatic infections. Only the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are being used in the United States. Britain is using both AstraZeneca’s and Pfizer’s. AstraZeneca’s has also been authorized by the 27-nation European Union. Pfizer has not endorsed the British government’s decision to lengthen the time between doses. Mene Pangalos, executive vice president of biopharmaceuticals research and development at AstraZeneca, said that no patients experienced severe Covid-19 or required hospitalization three weeks after receiving a first dose, and that effectiveness appeared to increase up to 12 weeks after the initial shot. “Our data suggest you want to be as close to the 12 weeks as you can” for the second dose, Pangalos said. British Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the study “backs the strategy that we’ve taken” to make sure more people have gotten at least one shot. Britain’s decision has been criticized as risky by other European countries. Stephen Evans of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine said the study’s suggestion that a single dose protected people for 12 weeks was “useful but not definitive.” Doctor Anil Mehta gives the AstraZeneca vaccine to a homeless person at the homeless accommodation YMCA in Romford, east London, Wednesday, Feb. 3, 2021. AP PHOTO He said that the authors themselves acknowledged their research was not designed to investigate the vaccine’s dosing schedule and that their conclusions were based on statistical modeling, not actual patients tracked over time. “It certainly isn’t very strong evidence, but there is also no indication this is the wrong thing to do,” Evans said of Britain’s strategy. One of the Oxford researchers, Dr. Andrew Pollard, said scientists also believe the AstraZeneca vaccine will continue to offer protection against new variants of Covid-19, though they are still waiting for data on that. Fast-spreading mutant versions have caused alarm around the world. “If we do need to update the vaccines, then it is actually a relatively straightforward process. It only takes a matter of months, rather than the huge efforts that everyone went through last year to get the very large-scale trials run,” Pollard told the BBC. Meanwhile, a UN-backed program to supply Covid-19 vaccines to the neediest people worldwide is gearing up after a troubled start. The Covax Facility announced plans Wednesday for an initial distribution of some 100 million doses by the end of March and more than 200 million more by the end of June to dozens of countries. Nearly all of the doses expected for the first phase are due to come from AstraZeneca and its partner, the Serum Institute of India. The rollout will be contingent on the World Health Organization authorizing the AstraZeneca shot for emergency use, which is expected to happen this month. Some 190 countries and territories are participating in Covax, which has seen rich nations scoop up vaccine supplies, sometimes at premium prices. The pandemic’s worldwide death toll has eclipsed 2.2 million, including about 447,000 in the US, according to Johns Hopkins University data. New cases per day in the US and the number of Americans in the hospital with Covid-19 have dropped sharply in the past few weeks, but deaths are still running at close to all-time highs at an average of around 3,100 a day. Deaths often lag behind the infection curve, because it can take weeks to sicken and die from Covid-19. As the Super Bowl approaches, Fauci is warning people against inviting others over for Super Bowl parties, urging viewers to “just lay low and cool it” to avoid turning Sunday’s big game into a super spreader event. “You don’t want parties with people that you haven’t had much contact with,” he told NBC’s “Today” show. “You just don’t know if they’re infected.”

headlines: Awakening from the darkest of dreams: Thomasian heroes who suffered from Covid-19
contents: BY STEPHANIE MAE AQUILINO AND HEART CATHERINE SOSA THE AQUINIAN, OFFICIAL STUDENT PUBLICATION UNIVERSITY OF SANTO TOMAS JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL ACADEMIC YEAR 2020-2021 (With minor editing, in accordance with The Manila Times style, the winning article in the Best Feature Story category (High School Level) of the 2020 Campus Press Awards is reprinted here in its entirety, with permission from the authors and the school.) The ticking of the clock subdues the usual lively noises of the room, its hands pointing toward the hour and minute of the time being. Dr. Carmina FuentebellaFACEBOOK PHOTO As the sun descends to rest, the moon reigns over the sky and the world is once again cloaked in darkness. Humanity then escorts itself to sleep after long hours of either finding their purpose in life or simply letting time pass by. In their deep slumber, they encounter a series of events psychologically as their physical body enjoys its rest. Their minds wander off to limitless worlds — terrains that could only be seen through closed eyes. The scenes are classified in two categories: delightful dreams and disastrous nightmares. They spend their whole night in those imaginary worlds, but as people say, there are dreams that come into reality. In today’s time, that ticking seems to be slower because of the 2019 coronavirus disease (Covid-19) pandemic. Indeed, it is the nightmare that made its way in the everyday life of humans. Thousands of people become infected everyday, and this global health crisis will continue on until a vaccine is released to the public in support of the declining number of positive cases in the country. Even modern heroes of the Thomasian community – teachers and doctors – are not exempted from this experience, as the darkness of the night once engulfed their skies. At the end of the night is a teacher from the University of Santo Tomas Junior High School (UST JHS) who experienced this nightmare, Frederick Caguioa. He is currently serving as a subject teacher in Mathematics for Grade 7 students and currently leads the Citizenship Advancement Training (CAdT) program for Grade 10 students. On July 19, 2020, he first felt the slight fever that was an indication that he might have contracted the disease. He stated that he slept on their sofa to protect his family and felt that his mind was spinning during the night. “So ang reason for that kasi, I usually go out if I needed to buy something sa Mercury Drug. Importante kasi dahil my wife actually gave birth last March lang, saktong ECQ pa so maliit pa ‘yung baby ko talaga. Eh, I usually go there to buy siyempre, ‘yung gatas. Ang naging problem namin is ‘yung anak ko, nag-diarrhea because of the milk, so we had to really change thrice. ‘Yun pala, kailangan talaga lactose-free na,” said Caguioa in an interview with The Aquinian. The next morning, he immediately looked for an institution that immediately released results, but a 24-hour result test costs P13,000. Caguioa said he already took the test despite the hefty price so that there would be peace and certainty. He prayed overnight that the results would be negative, but unfortunately, he tested positive for Covid-19. As a result, he contacted many people, including his cousin who is a doctor and some alumni of UST JHS, for advice on the steps that he must take as he was Covid-positive. For Caguioa, what made the night even darker was the fact that he was not accommodated by the UST Hospital. He felt both sadness and disappointment, and he was really angry because after all the years he spent in training and honing his young Thomasian students, he was turned down by the university itself on one of the most difficult moments of his life. “I even showed my ID. I even explained to them na I’ve been serving the university for quite some time. Ang word nila sa akin is ‘even sir kung maging critical ‘yung condition ninyo, we really cannot accommodate you here.’ So, I went back to the carpark, went back to my car and really prayed. Ano bang gagawin ko, Lord?” he lamented. Because of this, Caguioa had no other choice but to contact his closest friends, including some fellow faculty members. Feeling hopeless, Caguioa did not waste time in finding a place where his condition will be immediately attended to. Fortunately, his family roots had granted him a contact in his local barangay in Valenzuela, which assured his spot in a Covid-19 facility. Upon his stay in the facility, he was again battling with another enemy 一 being apart from his family for days more than the expected average 14-day Covid-19 infection. “The worst feeling is ‘yung hindi ako makabalik sa bahay for the longest time. Kasi to be honest with you, I went positive for 49 days,” Caguioa shared. When asked how Covid-19 negatively impacted him, he said it was the lost time being with his children. In fact, he also shared that his experience was agonizing because he could not see his children. He had set a wireless CCTV just to see and talk to his children while he was in the facility. “I even cried kasi, siyempre, we celebrate ‘yung monthly celebration ng baby namin. Even my birthday kasi I had my birthday on August 16, and I was still quarantined. Talagang wala, wala man lang celebration. Ako lang mag-isa rito. So, ayun talaga, sadness, loneliness, being away from my children and family,” he added. On the other hand, Caguioa stated that despite all the difficulties, his experience made him closer to God. In fact, during his stay in the facility, his companions constantly asked if he was a priest because he frequently prayed and wore a big rosary on his neck. He was taking the time in returning to his old self — specifically the time when he almost entered the seminary during his high school days. In addition, he said that one should be competent enough when caught in such a nightmare because there are seemingly endless challenges. “Kasi ang number one na nakalaban ko inside the facility is not the sickness itself; it’s all here in the mind. Actually, umabot na nang almost one month na mentally challenged ako. I almost went to depression, pero feel ko umabot na ako roon eh. Kasi hindi ko na alam ang gagawin ko,” stated Caguioa. Despite this, he remained steadfast because of the warriors that were praying for him, and he still has a mission to illuminate the terrains of his students. No doubt, Caguioa is a strong man for he was able to overcome a nightmare as murky as contracting the deadly Covid-19. “Have a stronger faith. Believe in the Lord. Siguro, mas mabigat lang ‘yung krus na pinabuhat sa atin, pero in the long run, baka may mas malaking nilalaan si Lord para sa atin. Kaya kailangan pagdaanan muna natin ‘to. I went through a bigger cross, so I can enjoy a bigger salvation,” he answered when asked what message would we like to impart to other Thomasians who are in the same situation as he were. Even heroes who are expected to save the people from all the dangers that the dark hours entail were not exempted from the nightmare Covid-19 has brought. Another Thomasian who was once immersed in this dark dream is Carmina Fuentebella. As a resident doctor in UST, Fuentebella had found herself in a hospital bed, living the nightmare brought by the pandemic. In fact, she even spent her 27th birthday facing the disease but on the receiving end of the care she used to give to her patients. “Sa una talaga, since marami naman akong na-handle na sakit and relatively bata lang kasi ako, hindi ako takot na nagka-Covid ako. ‘Yung mga kabarkada ko or mga co-residents ko, nagkaroon sila pero naka-admit lang sila tapos eventually gumaling din naman sila so nakauwi rin sila na walang problems. So, hindi talaga ako natatakot nung time na ‘yun,” said Fuentebella in an interview with The Aquinian. However, these thoughts were broken down as she laid in her hospital bed, severely suffering from the disease. As a person in a medical field, what she experienced in the span of time that she was in the hospital was beyond what she had ever expected. She couldn’t help but to find herself vulnerable, given that she was once the hero to people like her. It was easy for her to feel helpless by the thought that she was facing this nightmare alone. “Nung na-admit ako, dun ko na-feel na nagde-deteriorate ako nang konti. Nahihirapan ako huminga, tapos ‘yun nga na-intubate ako,” Fuentebella shared. Aside from the pain that she was experiencing, what stood out as the most painful experience was being separated from her family — the very own people who supported and gave her the opportunity to become a medical practitioner. With all these hardships, she found it inevitable to find herself miserable in the middle of the road. “Kasi ang mahirap kasi sa Covid is dealing with isolation. Kasi ikaw lang talaga lalaban mag-isa. Mag-isa ka sa room. May times na hindi ka talaga, wala ka talagang mapuntahan. Ikaw lang. Nakadepende ka kasi sa sarili mo, dun sa chat, and sa lakas ng loob mo na sana ma-overcome mo siya. Mahirap kasi sabihin na ‘kaya mo ‘yan’ kasi nung time talaga na ‘yun, point of giving up ako,” said Fuentebella. Confusion and pain were predominant during the span of staying in the hospital, given that it is inevitable when you are the one isolating because of the disease. With Covid-19, the actual enemy of patients is not only the virus, but also the psychological damage it brings to the patients. The virus lived in her mind, and she could not stop the thoughts about her occupation that kept on eating her alive. “Natakot ako nung una na parang sabi ko ayoko nang magdoktor, kasi honestly naman, as residents hindi ka naman ganun kalaking kumikita compared sa mga, pag nag-consultants na eh. Mapapaisip ka kung is it really worth it na kapag doktor ka, tas ‘pag nagkasakit ka uli, namatay ka, mawawala lahat ng mga dreams mo in the future, yung mga gusto mo pang gawin,” she added. Indeed, Covid-19 caused these individuals to shiver and almost succumb to the cold and detestable night. As they awakened from the darkest of dreams, they may still be recovering, but the strength in their hearts are stronger than ever. When the clock strikes the first hour of dawn, humans welcome yet another day filled with joy, relief, and even sorrow in the presence of the sun. For these heroes who battle in the education front and the receiving end of the pandemic, all the hours, minutes and seconds will be spent whatever the heart must do or what the heart desires, but one thing is for certain — they have proven that with hope and prayer, light will shine even through the most impenetrable darkness.

headlines: Comelec mulls shift from face-to-face to online campaign in 2022 polls
contents: ONLINE campaigning may be the new normal in the 2022 synchronized national and local elections amid coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) pandemic, according to the Commission on Elections (Comelec). Comelec spokesman James Jimenez said on Wednesday the poll body was considering temporarily prohibiting  the traditional “face-to-face” campaign in the wake of uncertainties on the start of the implementation of the country’s vaccination program. The poll body, Jimenez added, has sounded the alarm to the Inter-Agency Task Force on Emerging Infectious Diseases (IATF) to discuss the matter. Jimenez said, however, that any changes in the method of campaigning on radio and television would also need a corresponding amendment on related existing elections laws. The start of the campaign period is determined by the Omnibus Election Code (OEC), which is 90 and 45 days for national and local candidates respectively.The OEC also limits campaign spending of candidates. On the other hand, Republic Act (RA) 9006 or the Fair Elections Act regulates the size of printed campaign materials and limits television and radio advertisements. The Comelec noted that with some 80 million Filipinos who need to be vaccinated, the implementation of the vaccination program could last up to 2024. Jimenez said that in the absence of a herd immunity, it would be in the best interest of  all concerned to temporarily ban face-to-face campaigns to control the spread of Covid-19. During the 2019 polls, the Comelec, for the first time in the country’s political history, monitored the social media expenses of candidates and political parties.

headlines: 4 Metro Manila hospitals to receive Pfizer vaccines in Feb–Galvez
contents: DOCTORS, nurses and other medical personnel from four hospitals in Metro Manila that treat coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) patients will receive the initial doses of the vaccine from US pharmaceutical giant Pfizer, which will arrive in February. During the Laging Handa public briefing on Wednesday, Vaccine czar Carlito Galvez Jr. said about 58,000 health workers from the Philippine General Hospital (PGH), Jose N. Rodriguez Memorial Hospital and Sanitarium or Tala Hospital, Lung Center of the Philippines and the East Avenue Medical Center will be the beneficiaries of 117,000 Pfizer doses secured by the Philippine government through the Covax facility. Galvez said the medical frontliners will be inoculated two or three days after the arrival of the Pfizer vaccine which is expected by the second or third week. Galvez said other Covid-19 referral hospitals from Metro Manila, Cebu City and Davao City will also benefit from the initial doses of the Pfizer vaccines and those from AstraZeneca which is also expected to arrive in February. Galvez had announced that the Philippines will receive from 5.5 million to up to 9.2 million vaccines from AstraZeneca through the Covax facility.

headlines: PH records 1,583 new cases of Covid-19
contents: THE Philippines recorded 1,583 new cases of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) on Tuesday, according to the Department of Health (DoH), pushing the total number of infections to 528,853. Total active cases have reached 30,368 from which 95 percent are mild, moderate and asymptomatic. Thirty-nine more individuals survived the disease, increasing overall recovery to 487,611, or 92.2 percent of the total number of infections. There are 10,874 people who have died, including 67 recorded on Tuesday. A total of 17,682 tests were conducted by the country’s Covid-19 laboratories, from which 997 returned positive, for a positivity rate of 5.6 percent.

headlines: WHO slams critics of Covid-19 origins probe
contents: GENEVA: The World Health Organization on Monday blasted critics of its investigation into the origins of the Covid-19 pandemic and challenged those claiming to know better to come forward with the smoking gun. A WHO investigative team is in Wuhan, China — where the first cases were discovered in December 2019 — trying to piece together how the virus jumped from animals to humans before going on to kill more than two million people. The UN agency’s emergencies director Michael Ryan hit out at those sniping at the mission, and said people claiming they have information on how the pandemic broke out should emerge from the shadows. Ryan said many critics were saying they “won’t accept the report when it comes out”, or that there is “other intelligence available that may show different findings” on how the virus broke out. “If you have the answers… please let us know,” Ryan told a press conference from the WHO’s headquarters in Geneva. He asked how responsible it was “to say you won’t accept a report before it’s even written? To say that you have intelligence that has not been provided?” The WHO mission comes with heavy political baggage — China refused the team access until mid-January and there are question marks over what the experts can hope to find, one year on. Beijing is keen to put the focus on its recovery from the outbreak. The team toured a propaganda exhibition celebrating China’s recovery from the pandemic in Wuhan on Saturday. Ryan was responding to a question which referenced new US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, who earlier Monday told NBC that China was falling “far short of the mark.” “China has to step up and make sure that it is being transparent, that it is providing information and sharing information, that it is giving access to international experts and inspectors,” Blinken said. “Its failure to do that is a real problem.” Ryan said the team in the field deserved international support, and in the meantime, “it’s time for people who say and think they have information to start providing it”. He added that all infectious disease investigations find information that then throws up further questions. “It’s a detective story,” he said. Peter Daszak (r), Vladimir G. Dedkov( l) and other members of the World Health Organization  team investigating the origins of the Covid-19 leave the Hubei Center for animal disease control and prevention in Wuhan, China’s central Hubei province on February 2, 2021. AFP PHOTO The expert team in Wuhan has now started investigations on the ground, notably visiting the Huanan seafood market where one of the first reported clusters of infections emerged, and the hospital where early patients were treated. Maria Van Kerkhove, the WHO’s technical lead on Covid-19, said the team would be visiting the Wuhan Institute of Virology. Former US president Donald Trump pushed an unsubstantiated theory that the virus escaped from the facility. The team are having “very productive discussions with Chinese counterparts, visiting different hospitals around Wuhan,” Van Kerkhove said. “They had a very good visit to the market, seeing first-hand the stalls and walking through.” Van Kerkhove said they had also met with counterparts from the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention. “They will visit the Institute of Virology. That is being planned,” she added. Meanwhile WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said it was “encouraging” that the global number of new coronavirus cases had fallen for the third week in a row. “It shows this virus can be controlled, even with the new variants in circulation,” he said. However, “we have been here before,” he warned. “Over the past year, there have been moments in almost all countries when cases declined, and governments opened up too quickly and individuals let down their guard, only for the virus to come roaring back.”

headlines: ‘Just keep faith with us,’ Duterte on corruption allegations vs govt
contents: PRESIDENT Rodrigo Duterte has urged the public to keep their faith in his administration amid allegations of corruption in the government, particularly in the procurement of vaccines against the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). In his weekly public address aired over state-run PTV-4 on Monday evening, Duterte guaranteed that there were enough funds to pay for Covid-19 vaccines as he dismissed criticisms over the government’s rollout. He said the country’s “greatest disadvantage” was that it was not as rich as Western countries that have already pre-ordered 80 percent of the global vaccine supply, but assured that doses were forthcoming because “we have funds to pay for the vaccines”. He cited that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank have offered loans to pay for the vaccines that the government will buy. The government’s efforts to procure Covid-19 vaccines were once questioned due to the non-disclosure of actual prices of the vaccine. In Monday’s remarks, Duterte slammed critics claiming corruption in the government’s Covid-19 vaccine procurement anew, urging Filipinos not to believe in their false accusations. “Ang hingiin ko lang sana, patapusin mo lang ninyo lang kami (All I ask of you is for you to let us do our jobs first). If there is a liability in one, there will be a liability in all,” the President said. He told the public not to be “gullible” as to believe “talk about corruption left and right”. “It starts with a big bang and ends with a whimper. Wala naman napakulong ‘yang mga ‘yan (They have not sent anybody to prison),” he added. The President also promised to prove that vaccine procurement and rollout would be done “in accordance with the rule of law.” “I said, you have a choice, maniwala kayo sa kanila o maniwala kayo sa amin. Kung maniwala kayo sa kanila, go ahead (You can believe us or not. If you believe them, go ahead),” Duterte said. “Kung may maiwan na maniwala sa amin (If there will be those who will remain),  just keep faith with us. At the end of the day, you will see that everything has been done in accordance with the rule of law,” he added. The President likewise asked the public to trust that the country’s vaccine czar, Carlito Galvez Jr., would get vaccines for the Philippines. “Just stick with General Galvez. Huwag na kayong — huwag kayong lumipas sa kanya (Don’t overlook him) or ignore him and believe the others,” he said. Duterte also said that vaccine deals would not be final until it has been reviewed by Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez 3rd. On Monday, Galvez said the country has secured 106 to 108 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines after he signed five term sheets with manufacturers. READ: PH close to securing 188M doses of Covid-19 vaccines The Philippines hopes to secure some 148 million doses, aside from the 40 million doses that will come from the World Health Organization-led Covax Facility, to inoculate an initial 50 to 70 million Filipinos this year. To date, there are 527,272 Covid-19 cases in the Philippines, 10,807 deaths, and 487,574 recoveries.

headlines: SWS: Unemployment hits record-high 37.4% in 2020
contents: JOBLESSNESS among adults in the country rose to its highest in eight years in 2020, according to the latest survey conducted by the Social Weather Stations (SWS) amid the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) pandemic. According to the poll conducted from November 21 to 25 among 1,500 respondents nationwide, SWS recorded the highest average unemployment rate since it started analyzing these figures, currently sitting at 37.4 percent. The average joblessness rate for 2020 was a 8.6-percentage point increase from the previous record of 28.8 percent in 2012 and the 19.8 percent recorded in 2019, or before the pandemic hit the country. In the latest SWS survey, joblessness was at 27.3 percent of the adult labor force, down by 12 points from the 39.5 percent in September 2020. “The estimated numbers of jobless adults are 12.7 million in November 2020 and 23.7 million in September 2020,” SWS said. “Joblessness was 17.5 percent in December 2019, the last measurement before the Covid-19 crisis began,” the polling firm added. SWS defines labor force as those 18 years and above and presently with a job, including those looking for a job. Adults who are jobless consists of those who voluntarily left their old jobs, are seeking jobs for the first time, or lost their jobs due to economic circumstances beyond their control. SWS estimated 12.7 million jobless adult Filipinos in November 2020, lower than the 23.7 million in September 2020. “The 12-point decline in the national joblessness rate was due to decreases of 33 points in the Visayas, 23 points in Mindanao, two points in Metro Manila, and one point in Balance Luzon,” SWS said. Adult joblessness fell sharply in the Visayas, from a record-high 52.0 percent in September 2020 to 19.1 percent in November 2020. It fell sharply in Mindanao, from 40.0 percent in September 2020 to 17.0 percent in November 2020. Adult joblessness fell slightly in Balance Luzon, from 33.5 percent in September 2020 to 32.7 percent in November 2020. It also fell slightly in Metro Manila, from 39.9 percent in September 2020 to 37.8 percent in November 2020. The fourth quarter 2020 SWS survey, conducted using face-to-face interviews, had sampling error margins of ±2.5 percent for national percentages, ±4 percent for Balance Luzon, and ±6 percent for Metro Manila, the Visayas, and Mindanao.

headlines: GOCCs’ P119-B dividends allocated for Covid efforts
contents: The Department of Finance (DoF) said a total of P119.1 billion or bulk of the P157-billion cash dividends remitted by government-owned and controlled corporations (GOCCs) in 2020 partly funded the Social Amelioration Program (SAP) to ease the economic impact of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) pandemic on poorest households and vulnerable sectors. In a statement, the DoF’s Corporate Affairs Group (CAG) said the P156.97 billion in dividends remitted last year by 57 GOCCs to the Bureau of the Treasury (BTr) was the highest amount ever collected since the implementation of Republic Act (RA) 7656 or the “Dividends Law of 1994.” “This is also more than twice of the P69.17 billion dividend collection in 2019, inclusive of the dividend foregone. Without dividends foregone, cash remittances is P135.08 billion in 2020 and P52.59 billion in 2019,” the CAG headed by Finance Undersecretary Antonette Tionko said in a report to Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez 3rd. Tionko said that P119.1 billion of the GOCCs’ dividend remittances contributed to the government’s unprogrammed revenues. “These GOCC dividends were primarily utilized  for the Social Amelioration Program, which provided emergency assistance to low-income families to help tide them over during the strict lockdowns imposed earlier last year to curb the spread of Covid-19,” Tionko said. This year, Tionko said the CAG will continue to make sure that GOCCs will comply with ra 7856 and its implementing rules and regulations. She said the CAG was able to secure an agreement with the Governance Commission for GOCCs (GCG) in 2020 for the transfer of the web-based GOCC Debt Recording and Monitoring System (GDRAMS) to the DoF. This reporting system aims to streamline the data reporting process and facilitate the timely encoding and submission of the GOCCs of their debt reports, Tionko said. “GDRAMS will help in the analysis of GOCC debt and better manage the government’s financial exposure and strategy formulation,” Tionko said. She said the DoF will further enhance the GDRAMS and train GOCCs on the use of the system so it could be fully implemented this year.

headlines: Gasly becomes latest F1 driver to test positive for Covid-19
contents: PARIS: French driver Pierre Gasly on Sunday (Monday in Manila) became the sixth Formula One driver to test positive for Covid-19 but insisted: “I’m feeling OK”. The 24-year-old AlphaTauri driver said he was self-isolating at home. “I wanted to let you know that I have tested positive for Covid-19. I have told everyone I have been in contact with during these last few days,” Gasly wrote in a statement on Twitter. “I am feeling OK and will continue to follow my training plan from home while I remain in isolation.” Gasly, who claimed a career first win at the Italian Grand Prix last season and finished 10th in the standings, is the latest star of the F1 grid to test positive in recent months. World champion Lewis Hamilton missed the Sakhir GP in Bahrain before returning for the season finale in Abu Dhabi. Earlier this month, Ferrari driver Charles Leclerc announced he had tested positive for Covid-19, two days after Formula One was forced to postpone two of this season’s Grands Prix in Australia and China. British McLaren driver Lando Norris tested positive while on holiday in Dubai after the conclusion of the 2020 season. Sergio Perez tested positive for the coronavirus and missed last season’s British Grand Prix. His Racing point teammate Lance Stroll had to sit out the Eifel Grand Prix in Germany because of the virus.

headlines: Mexican president hopeful he can beat Covid
contents: MEXICO CITY: Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said on Friday (Saturday in Manila) he was hopeful that he was through the worst of his coronavirus infection as he reappeared in a video message to the nation. Handout picture released by Mexico’s Presidency press office showing Mexico’s President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador delivering a speach during the inauguration of the new facilities for the National Guard in San Luis Potosi, Mexico on January 24, 2021. (Photo by Handout / Mexican Presidency / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE – MANDATORY CREDIT “AFP PHOTO / MEXICAN PRESIDENCY” – NO MARKETING NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS – DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS “I still have Covid, but the doctors already tell me that the critical phase is passing,” said the 67-year-old from the National Palace, where he has his office and official residence. “Now I present myself to you so that there are no rumors,” he added in the video posted on social media. “I’m fine although I still have to rest,” he said in a steady voice. Dressed in a suit, tie and overcoat — but without a face mask — he is seen walking and talking for around 13 minutes through the National Palace. Lopez Obrador said he was working while in isolation, in particular on efforts to secure more vaccines for Mexico, which has one of the world’s highest Covid-19 death tolls at more than 156,000. The country began a mass immunization program on December 24 but like many nations it is struggling to acquire enough doses. Lopez Obrador said Mexico expected to receive six million doses from various manufacturers in February and 12 million in March, by when it hopes to have given a first shot to all older adults. The left-wing populist, who has a history of heart problems and hypertension, announced Sunday that he was undergoing treatment for Covid-19 but had mild symptoms. He joins other world leaders who have caught the virus, including former US president Donald Trump, Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and French President Emmanuel Macron. The health ministry reported on Wednesday that Lopez Obrador had experienced brief episodes of low-grade fever and a slight headache. The Mexican leader has refused to wear a mask except on rare occasions during the pandemic. He was accused by critics of downplaying the risks of the virus early in the crisis and of being slow to impose a lockdown. Both new coronavirus infections and deaths have set daily records this month, leaving hospitals overwhelmed, particularly in Mexico City, which has been in a state of maximum alert since mid-December.

headlines: Virtus Awards keeps silver lining in sight for hotel industry
contents: The sudden shifts and slowdown of business due to the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic greatly affected the hospitality industry in 2020. According to the Department of Tourism (DoT), from January to November 2020, the country’s tourism receipts fell by 81 percent to P81.5 billion, a significant drop from P437.9 billion in the same period in 2019. International arrivals, meanwhile, also dropped by 82.4 percent to 1.3 million compared to the 7.4 million recorded from January to November in 2019. Outstanding Marketing Campaign winner Sofitel Philippine Plaza Manila Despite this major setback, the hotel and tourism industry continued to prove their resilience. The stakeholders explored ways to restart and offset the crisis’ impact on their sector. Adapting to survive In a press conference just before the end of 2020, the Hotel Sales and Marketing Association (HSMA) — a premier organization of sales and marketing leaders in the Philippine travel and tourism industry — assessed what the sector had to face the entire 2020 and shared some of the adjustment they adapted to survive. Champions of Resilience Marketing Communications, Chroma Hospitality “It brought out the best in us. There were times that we thought we can’t do it anymore because some of the hotels were closed for two months, we didn’t have a job that’s why my heart goes out to the people that really struggled,” recalled Christine Ann Ibarreta, President of HSMA Board for 2021-2022 and Group Director of Sales and Marketing of Golden Phoenix Hotels. Champion of Resilience Team, Luxent Hotel headed byGeneral Manager Melanie Pagkalinawan “In spite of the troubles we went through, we were together looking for business for each other. If my hotel was not open, I was there to help out other colleagues in the industry. We made our HSMA e-store where our member hotels can sell anything so that they would have a source of income. We also tried to share in terms of bookings,” Ibarreta continued. Ibarreta also recalled how they sealed partnership with Philippine Airlines that entailed them having a hospitality desk at the Terminal 2 of Philippine Airlines. “We were there to volunteer, we provided snacks, coffee to the arriving OFWs and balikbayans. We’re happy to be of service. It’s about bayanihan and the love for our job. I believe that after all of these, they will see that we really helped out each other, there’s love for our job and our dedication,” she added. Outstanding Sales and Marketing Manager winner PioSanchez, Senior Sales Manager of El Nido Resorts According to the organization, they were able to handle the difficult situation by collaborating hand in hand with the government sector. “This is a year of a stronger collaboration. The silver lining this year especially for the hotels in Metro Manila, as you know, is the OFWs and balikbayans. The government partnered with a lot of hotels to become quarantine hotels for Filipinos coming back home,” shared Pearl Maclang, Marco Polo Davao’s Director of Sales & Marketing and HSMA Director for Public Relations. “Without them, a lot of the hotels would have been in trouble and that’s what happened with the hotels outside National Capital Region because of the closure of the airports, stricter quarantine protocols and limited market,” Maclang added. Outstanding Sales and Marketing Associate winnerErika Denice Patajo, Events Executive of Okada Manila Maclang reiterated that a stronger collaboration of HSMA, Tourism Promotions Board and the Department of Tourism, allowed the group to stimulate the market to prepare for 2021. “Because to be honest, there’s nothing much we can do, it’s beyond our control. We must address all these changes that happened in 2020 a lot faster, more creative and resilient,” she continued. Throughout the year, hotels also had to update their operational infrastructure and steadily shift many of their platforms to new-age solutions. “Given we’re in a new situation, we can’t be stuck with the old ideas so we encouraged our hotels and resorts to rethink our business model and to adapt to market conviction so that we will have a better chance to survive 2021 and even succeed,” Ma. Celeste Romualdo, General Manager of The Linden Suites and HSMA’s Director for Membership. Finding solutions to thrive In the hopes of thriving this 2021, HSMA laid down several suggestions that they hope would help the industry. Two of them stood out, aligned rules and regulations for tourists and subsidized swab testing. Champion of Resilience Individual, Elena CecilleDaugdaug of Quest Cebu “The Department of Tourism is pushing the local government units to have a same requirements when it comes to rules and regulations. They should have an alignment meeting because they have different requirements per city,” Rose Libongco, HSMA co-founder and Virtus Awards Chair said. Ibarreta, meanwhile, suggested, “We have to thank Tourism Promotions Board COO Anthonette Velasco-Allones and Tourism Secretary Bernadette Romulo-Puyat because I think they’ve subsidized swab testing. For the special rate, it is now only for P1,500. But it will be a boost if tourist won’t have to pay for swab testing anymore.” Virtus Awards 2020 Looking at the bright side, the event also saw the annual Virtus Awards. Indeed, HSMA still found a way to recognize the most creative, productive and proactive hotel sales and marketing professionals who were more than resilient in the face of a pandemic. Outstanding Sales and Marketing Leaders winner EunJoo Bae, Director of Sales-FIT at Conrad Manila The highlight of the prestigious event was the Champions of Resilience Awards, created to recognize the contributions of individuals and institutional team/s in addressing the challenges of the pandemic. The Champions of Resilience Awards are divided into three categories: Individual – which was won by Ma. Elena Cecille Daugdaug, Sales Manager of Quest Hotel and Conference Center Cebu; Team – won by Luxent Hotel under the leadership of Melanie Pagkalinawan, General Manager; and Marketing Communications – won by Chroma Hospitality, as led by Carmela Bocanegra, Vice President for Sales and Marketing. As in previous Virtus Awards, honors were given to the Outstanding Sales and Marketing Associate, which was conferred to Erika Denice Patajo, Events Executive of Okada Manila; and Outstanding Sales and Marketing Manager for Pio Sanchez, Senior Sales Manager of El Nido Resorts.
